optwrf.test¶

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics¶

Tests the optimize_wrf_physics functions

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_generate_random_dates()¶

Check if start and end dates can be randomly generated.

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_get_wrf_fitness()¶

Checks to see if the WRF fitness can be calculated for the default simulaiton. For this, you must be on Magma, Cheyenne, or AWS.

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_print_database()¶

Checks to see if the contnts of a database can be successfully printed to the screen.

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_run_simplega()¶

Tests the genetic algroithm framework without running WRF.

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_seed_initial_population()¶

Check that individuals specified via an input CSV file can be used to create an initial population.

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_sql_to_csv()¶

Checks the function that writes the SQL database to a CSV file.

optwrf.test.test_optimize_wrf_physics.test_update_sim()¶

Checks to make sure that entries in the database can be updated.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_postwrf¶

Tests the runwrf functions after WRF has been run

There is no test for run_wps(), run_real(), or run_wrf() because these programs are all computationally expensive and I don’t want them in this test suite. To test if WPS, REAL, and WRF are running correctly, I should probably make a separate test, but right now, I have been using runwrf_fromCL.py for this purpose.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_postwrf.test_process_era5_data()¶
optwrf.test.test_runwrf_postwrf.test_process_wrfout_data()¶
optwrf.test.test_runwrf_postwrf.test_wrf_era5_diff()¶

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup¶

Tests the runwrf functions before WRF has been run

There is no test for optwrf.runwrf.run_real() or optwrf.runwrf.run_wrf() because these programs are all computationally expensive, and I don’t want them in this test suite. To test if REAL and WRF are running correctly, I should probably make a separate test, but right now, I have been using runwrf_fromCL.py for this purpose.

I can’t really think of a good way to test determine_computer without having to call the function over and over again in subsequent tests, so I’m just going to omit it for now.

Some of the tests will only be useful if you’re on a machine with the WRF source code downloaded (i.e., Magma, Cheyenne, or AWS). Otherwise, the test will automatically pass.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup.test_WRFModel()¶

Checks that the WRFModel method works correctly. The assert statements assume that you are using dirpth.yml not one made for a local machine. Should probably change this at some point…

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup.test_format_date()¶

Checks the function that ensures consistency in the input date format.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup.test_get_bc_data(setup_yaml='mac_dirpath.yml')¶

Checks if WRF boundary condition data can be downloaded from the RDA. This definitely works best if done on Magma using setup_yaml=’dirpath.yml’, but if you do want to run it on your local machine make sure that you change setup_yaml=’local_dirpath.yml’, where local_dirpath.yml is a yaml file where you specify root directory paths.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup.test_prepare_namelists()¶

If on AWS, Cheyenne, or Magma, tests that the template namelists can be edited to reflect the desired configuration for the current WRF model run.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup.test_run_wps()¶

If on AWS, Cheyenne, or Magma, tests that WPS runs successfully.

optwrf.test.test_runwrf_setup.test_wrfdir_setup()¶

If on AWS, Cheyenne, or Magma, tests that the WRF directory can be setup correclty.
